head.title: Vanguard Group Trims Fees for Advisers

identified-content.classifier: Top/Classifieds/Job Market/Job Categories/Banking, Finance and Insurance

hedline.hl1: Vanguard Group Trims Fees for Advisers

block.p: Vanguard Group, the nation's No. 2 mutual fund company, is cutting the fees it pays investment advisers for 17 of its biggest funds, including its flagship Windsor Fund.
The company said today that the reductions totaled about $10 million a year. Fund fees were lowered by as much as 45 percent, and the average fee was cut 18 percent, the company said.
Vanguard Group, the nation's No. 2 mutual fund company, is cutting the fees it pays investment advisers for 17 of its biggest funds, including its flagship Windsor Fund.
The company said today that the reductions totaled about $10 million a year. Fund fees were lowered by as much as 45 percent, and the average fee was cut 18 percent, the company said.
Annual advisory fees for the Windsor Fund, for example, will be cut 20 percent, to a maximum of 20.9 basis points, or $2.09 per $1,000 invested, the company said.

Vanguard, already considered the industry's low-cost company, said it was reducing fees in the wake of a "substantial climb" in fund assets last year. The last time Vanguard cut its investment advisory fees was in 1993.
